content:
Will the installation instructions for Lean 3 stay under this link for the upcoming years?
https://leanprover-community.github.io/get_started.html

Or, will Lean 4 installation get this URL and the Lean 3 instructions will be moved elsewhere?
My understanding from the recent porting meeting is that this sort of thing is still under discussion.
Thank you for the answer, even though it is the least convenient answer I could hear.
Actually, since it is on GitHub pages, I should be able to generate a permanent link to the current version, assuming I don't need the menu on the left, just the rendered markdown file, right?
I would expect that in 6 months time that URL will not even mention Lean 3.
(I hope that we deprecate Lean 3 as quickly as possible once mathlib4 is ready to go. :-)

I guess the best permalink to the Lean 3 installation instructions will be the following:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/leanprover-community.github.io/blob/662aaab1d374a90d85a26e405a1fac698304a281/templates/get_started.md
Martin Dvořák has marked this topic as resolved.
Can I ask why you want a long term URL?

ITP paper will point to my repository
https://github.com/madvorak/grammars/tree/publish
which points to a manual how to install Lean 3 so that future readers can compile it.

Martin Dvořák said:

I guess the best permalink to the Lean 3 installation instructions will be the following:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/leanprover-community.github.io/blob/662aaab1d374a90d85a26e405a1fac698304a281/templates/get_started.md

I am using this link in the end. It isn't pleasant to read but will be practically immortal.

If you want proper long-term reproducibility, make a VM with your project and all dependencies installed and upload it to Zenodo or equivalent. Anything else will invariably rot in some way within 5-10 years. See for example these guidelines we made for ICFP this year.
An immortal link to installation instructions isn't very useful if the things those instructions link to no longer exist

Jannis Limperg said:

If you want proper long-term reproducibility, make a VM with your project and all dependencies installed and upload it to Zenodo or equivalent. Anything else will invariably rot in some way within 5-10 years. See for example these guidelines we made for ICFP this year.

Good to know for the next time. Thanks!
